By integrating diverse data sources, Adriano's work facilitates broad scientific applications, enhancing the capability for search and discovery in the astronomical community.

Danylo is deeply interested in the field of photonics and plasmonics, focusing his research on the fundamental understanding and practical applications of these phenomena in spectroscopy and beyond. Danylo is passionate about integrating chemometrics and machine learning techniques into his research in spectroscopy and quantum photonics. Zhihui is keenly interested in the application of machine learning techniques, particularly Boosted Decision Trees (BDTs) and Neural Networks (NNs), to structured and numerical data. His research emphasizes the role of the mass ratio and orbital eccentricity of binary stars in influencing planetary stability and habitability. By categorizing planetary habitability into various classes—habitable, periodic habitable, and non-habitable—Zhihui develops machine-learning models to classify these systems efficiently, aiding in the prediction and discovery of potentially habitable worlds beyond our solar system.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Rommulus is deeply fascinated by the vast and intriguing realms of astrophysics and cosmology. Through these areas, Rommulus seeks to unravel the cosmic mysteries and contribute to the broader field of cosmology.

Bo is deeply involved in researching galaxies and active galactic nuclei (AGNs) at moderate to high redshifts. Bo's research aims to elucidate the coevolution of dark matter and stellar mass assembly, which is essential for grasping the broader narrative of cosmic evolution. research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Sune is highly interested in the application of machine learning techniques to solve complex geophysical problems. This is particularly relevant in the study of climatic and geological changes recorded over time, enabling more accurate predictions and insights. Machine learning offers the potential to uncover patterns and trends that might not be immediately visible through traditional methods, thereby significantly enhancing the understanding of geophysical dynamics and processes. Sune aims to leverage these advanced techniques to tackle some of the pressing questions in climate physics, ultimately contributing to more robust models and simulations.

Sune's research explores the intricate relationship between volcanic activity and abrupt climate change events during the last glacial period. His work seeks to understand how volcanic eruptions may have triggered significant climatic shifts, such as the Dansgaard-Oeschger events and Heinrich stadials. By analyzing high-resolution ice-core data, Sune investigates the temporal correlation between volcanic eruptions and climate changes, shedding light on volcanic influences on climatic systems at critical tipping points. This research not only enhances the understanding of historical climate variability but also provides insights into potential future climatic responses to large-scale volcanic eruptions.

An essential component of Sune's research is the establishment and refinement of the Greenland Ice-Core Chronology (GICC). This work centers around creating precise and robust time scales for interpreting paleoclimate data, critical for understanding the Earth's historical climate patterns. Sune aims to enhance the accuracy and precision of ice core dating by integrating various methods, including annual-layer counting and alignment with radiometric timescales using reference horizons like volcanic markers. His research facilitates the comparative study of paleoclimate archives, decreasing uncertainties and improving correlations between different climate records, thereby advancing the field of paleoclimatology.

Jinglin is deeply engaged in optimizing strategies for detecting exoplanets, particularly using radial velocity methods. This technique involves observing the 'wobble' of a star caused by the gravitational pull of orbiting planets. Jinglin's work addresses major challenges in this field, such as distinguishing true planetary signals from stellar and instrumental noise. By refining data analysis techniques, including signal disentanglement using Fourier analysis and other sophisticated modeling, Jinglin seeks to improve the precision of detecting smaller exoplanets that reside within their star's habitable zone. This effort not only assists in cataloging more exoplanets but also contributes to understanding the demographics of planetary systems beyond our own.

Jinglin conducts research focusing on understanding and mitigating the effects of stellar activity and instrumental variability, which pose significant challenges in the field of precise exoplanetary detection. Stellar phenomena such as pulsations and spots can lead to apparent shifts in spectral lines, complicating the identification of planet-induced signals. Jinglin utilizes a range of analytical frameworks to separate these effects, thereby enhancing the reliability of detected signals attributed to planetary companions. This research is pivotal not only in aiding accurate detection of exoplanets but also in advancing the field of precision astronomy, preparing it for future missions that aim to directly image exoplanetary systems.
